awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Tracking magmatic and volcanic changes in the May 2018 Kilauea Eruption.
awd_abstract_narration:
This Rapid Research Response (RAPID) award will enable a detailed study of the May 2018 eruption in an effort to reconstruct lava emplacement within and between several sites spread out over about 10 km of the volcano's east rift zone. By coupling this information to lava and crystal cargo compositional analyses, the study will aim to answer questions about the magmatic system and magma migration pathways leading to this unanticipated eruption. Microtextural analysis of samples that are contextualized with aerial imagery will permit critical evaluation of existing flow emplacement models and thus engender improved quantitative understanding of lava flow dynamics. By comparing geochemical and petrologic results to the geophysical signals, the project will enhance understanding about how and why volcanoes erupt.

This RAPID award will support short-fuse, high resolution geochemical studies of lava flows from the Kilauea volcano eruption in May 2018. It is planned to use 210Po-210Pb-226Ra, petrologic analysis of eruption products, and rheological evolution of basaltic lava, all in a tightly constrained spatio-temporal context. Despite the unfortunate interaction of eruption fissures with personal property and infrastructure, this eruption represent an excellent opportunity to investigate magmatism at one of Earth's most active volcanoes, with implications for why, when, and how volcanic activity occurs at a particular location. The unprecedented geophysical record of events leading to and during the eruption from the US Geological Survey's Hawaii Volcano Observatory (HVO) dense observational network, and strong partnership and collaboration with HVO colleagues for sample collection and eruption parameter observations, and the excellent lava sample suite that is and will be collected for this study, makes this a truly unique opportunity to address fundamental scientific questions about magmatic processes within a volcanic rift zone and flow emplacement mechanics during opening phases of fissure-fed lava effusion. Volcanic products from the new/ongoing rift zone eruption have been sampled for us by the USGS, with more collections forthcoming.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This RAPID project arose in the early days of what would prove to be one of the most dramatic and impactful eruptions of Kīlauea volcano in the past 50 years, providing the opportunity to  study various aspects of the then-ongoing 2018 volcanic eruption in ways that would not be possible after the eruption ceased. This was 4 semi-independent sub-projects run in parallel and funded together at the request of the NSF, via PI Rubin and co-PIs Garcia, Hammer, and Shea (listed in alphabetical order) 

The primary goals included (1) a lava flow rheology study, where we applied and dynamic models for predicting lava flow behavior, (2) the use of the textural and geochemical characteristics of minerals, volcanic glass and melt inclusions to examine  the timing of magma recharge and mixing prior to and during eruption, (3) use of major element characteristics of erupted lavas to evaluate how and where they were formed, and (4) examination of short-lived, naturally-occurring radioactive isotopes in erupted materials (including 210Po, with a half life of 138 days) to examine the timing and sequence of magma eruption and degassing, as well as to examine the conditions of pre-eruptive magma accumulation and residence in shallow reservoirs. Secondary goals included (1) establishing richer and more streamlined interactions between University of Hawaii and USGS Hawaiian Volcano Observatory scientists for active eruption studies and (2) to conduct science communication to the general public of research results and about eruptive activity at Kīlauea, using pre-existing social and regular media channels that PI Rubin runs or collaborates with.

Summary of Results:

• Identification of multiple different batches of magma during the eruption, which mix together in less than 100 days prior to eruption.

• Simple models of lava flow emplacement based on their physical characteristics work sufficiently well to describe attributes such as width and length when their effusion rate is at steady-state, but do not work well when there are variations in effusion over time.

• Recognition that Kīlauea's east rift zone is more complicated how it stores and transmits magma from previous and ongoing eruptions than previously thought.

• Identification of variable metal degassing and condensation conditions before and during eruption, implying either incomplete magma degassing during ascent/eruption or mixing of shallow storage/partial degassed magmas with less degassed materials during eruption, as well as variable condensation of Po vapor from the eruption cloud onto volcanic ejecta (minor amounts occurred during the 2018 eruption, but major activity in the subsequent December 2020 summit eruption, perhaps related to the presence of a water lake in Hale’mau’mau crater before this eruption).

Modified by: Kenneth H Rubin
